column4: hey all, i found an app that saved all the data off my dying drive. i'm now getting ready to send the drive back for a replacement and want to make sure it's as wiped as possible. any pointers on the best way to do that?
get a package called "wipe" - and run a program called "wipe".  it - um - wipes things :)
just a bunch of one's and zero's is probably fine. there's no real sensitive data on there.
read the 'wipe' man page.  it includes the term "rising totalitarianism"
ok.
the author of wipe clearly thinks that his hard-disks are working against him.
i've met people like that. i know one guy that takes old drives apart and melts 'em to dispose of them.
my Dad took an electric drill to his last PC's hard-disk before throwing it out!
then there's my uncle who does his bills and taxes on his computer and puts it out on the curb every time he gets a virus he can't fix. *rolls eyes*
The best way  to sanitize a storage medium  is to subject it to  temperatures exceeding 1500K.   As a  cheap alternative, you might  use wipe at  your own risk.
i think throwing it in the pond in my backyard might take care of it too. what do i know though? :-)

i do agree with the first sentence of his description though. i threw dozens of linux and windows of programs at this drive that couldn't read a thing and finally found one that read every bit of data on the drive. quite amazing.
what eventually worked for you?
$80 was a small price to pay for 300Gb worth of data!
thanks.  you never know when such information might be handy.
this wipe guy scares me. this isn't going to secretly going to wipe data i want is it? ;-)
he sounds to me like he's just wanting to make absolutely sure you don't sue him in the unlikely event that there's a bug in his program
i highly recommend it. it worked flawlessly and they even let me keep the more expensive physical media they accidentally shipped me. good people.
it's funny that the only 'disk rescue' program you found that worked with your linux filesystems is a windows program!
ironically, most of the data recovery software i found was windows only - even if it was for rescuing linux or mac filesystems. *shrug*
have you used wipe? he suggests not wiping a whole disk (/dev/hdc), but a partition, so you don't kill an MBR. this is just a data drive though.
i know what a good test would be.... to see if the data recovery can read any data after i run wipe on this drive! :-)
I would be very surprised if it does.  just from the tone of the wipe man page I think this guy would have done a good job with 'wipe'
